Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 12:29PM Goldie wrote: I too have a terrible family history when it comes to cancer on both sides and Have three small daughters I have to stick around for.  I'm going to the University of Michigan Medical Center and while my doctor advised a lumpectomy w/rad or mastecotomy on the left; I'm asking for a double and possibly a hysterecomy down the road all for preventive reasons.  I'm trying to consider what will give me the best chance at avoiding recurrance, since numerous mammos never caught my first cancer I can't assume I'll have an chance at early detection on the right. Sounds like the Mayo Clinic has your best interest in mind. But it's obviously your decision to make. I just know I need to be ablet o tell my daughters one day I did everything possible. Good luck with whatever you choose and God bless you!  Goldie
Posts.Title: What choice would you make? AndreaM4567 Beesie

Posts.Content: Goldie wrote: For the past several months I had discharge from one breast and immediately went to my gyn who sent me to a breast specialist.  I had 2 mammos and ultrasound, both were negative.  The breast specialist spent some time lecturing me about not being obsessed with fear, etc. I've been getting mammograms since I was 38 because my mom had bc. In the fall, the discharge became red.  I again went to the doctor the next day.  They couldn't get a sample and said to keep an eye on it.  Three weeks ago, the discharge returned, bloody again.  I went to the doctor the next day and he sent me to a breast specialist and requested an MRI.  The MRI came back positive and I had a biopsy last Tuesday. I was told it was malignant and had left the duct, but appearred to be in early stage.. He wouldn't know if any lymphnodes were affected until he went back in. I'm so angry right now.  I spent all that time trying to find out what was wrong, the mammograms were useless and if not for this MRI (which the insurance company almost didn't pay for) it would be spreading even more! I'm so scared.  I'm only 41 with three small girls.  I find out more Tuesday.  All the doctor said on thephone was we would discuss lumpectomy vs. masectomy.  I need to be here for my daughters. Has anyone else h Dx 2/21/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: It took an MRI to find my cancer Goldie Goldie

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 02:08PM Goldie wrote: Me again.  I'm going back to the surgeon Tuesday for more info on my biopsy.  I just keep hearing in my head when I asked him if it looked early or advanced, he said it looked early and had told my husband he got all of the mass he wanted.  He first told my husband after the biopsy that it looked like nothing to him.  I keep trying to hold on to anything positive and hoping that it really is "early" and he wouldn't just say that.  Also, it's crazy but I keep thinking if it didn't look like anything to him when he removed it, could it mean the tumor or whatever is still pretty small? Like everyone else here I'm terrified and fearing that this has spread all over and I won't get to see my 3 girls grow up!!
Posts.Title: It took an MRI to find my cancer Goldie Goldie

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2008 11:44AM Goldie wrote: Anniee, Thanks for the words.  Yes, this definitely could have been caught sooner.  We, of course, rely on doctors to know what they're talking about and I realize they're onlyhuman, but if there is more that can be done, why not do it!!  The discharge was not spontaneous and only came out if I expressed it.  it was never milky, but golden like columstrum at first and then became bloody later. Maybe because it wasn't spontaneous is why they weren't concerned.  They were sure it was a papilloma.  However, it may still be just that and the discharge may not be related to the cancer.  I just don't know enough yet. I'm just so grateful my ob/gyn was the one who listened to me and ordered teh MRI.  I'm praying the MRI picked up on it early and that's why it didn't come up on mammos. Thanks for the prayers,
Posts.Title: It took an MRI to find my cancer Goldie Goldie

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 04:31PM Goldie wrote: Hi all.  Well, met with doctor today to go over my pathology after my dx last thurday.  BC caught on MRI that I had to keep asking for after repeated negative mammos. left breast only. It showed I have invasive ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, grade 2, that represents 25% of a 5 x 2 cm mass.  So that part has left the duct. In addition, it showed 75% of the tumor to be DCIS. He cateogorized me overall as Stage 1, even though the tumor is considered large but because it is DCIS it's good, I guess, and means I've been caught early. He did not give me a hard time about preventive mastecomy on healthy breast, but wants me to see psycholgist first just to make sure I'm thinking clearly. No problem there!  Also, he doubts radiation, but thinks they might lean towards chemo afterwards as an insurance policy. I suppose it's the best news I could have gotten going in today. Now the next huge scare is the bone scan and chest xray on Thursday. Then surgery to find out if any lymphnodes affected.  Dr. said no way to know now even with the pathology if any affected. Anyone out there have two differents types of breast cancer at the same time at stage 1?  And, if so, did you have lymphnode involvement, chest, bones? He said my prognosis is good.  If lymphnodes invovled, not as good, and means more work/treatment.  I already told him I want a double mastecomy Any feedback would be great.  I'm feeling a little better today at least with some information and knowing stage 1, but now fearing the bone scan, chest and lymphnodes issues. Anyone with similar case or thoughts on how this pathology sounds? Now I'm going tomorrow for the bone scan and chest xray.  I'm so terrified this might be found somewhere else.  ANyone have any thoughts or experience with the chances of mets with the patholody I described?  I'm going to be seen at the University of Michigan Medical Center on Monday.  It's suppose to be one of the best in the midwest.  I'm fortunate to live near by. Thanks, Goldie
Posts.Title: It took an MRI to find my cancer Goldie Goldie

Posts.Content: Goldie wrote: Wanted to report that I had my unilateral mastecomy yesterday, rather than the lump/radiation my surgeon suggested.  I'm incredibly sore, but not bad.  He had to take out a small portion of chest muscle to make sure he had good margins, so that explains some of the pain. My sentinal node injection highlighted 3-4 nodes that were first in line.  He did pathology on one right away that looked enlarged to him, but thankfully that came back negative while he was still operating.  Now all I need to do is wait for the comlete path. on the other 3 he took out.  The dye injection indicated a small group of sentinal nodes rather than just one. So, here's praying the other nodes are okay, because I know that's what we all want for ourselves and each other. Thanks for everyone's support on my previous posts and I'm sure I'll have more.  I don't know yet if I'll need chemo, but of course, whatever it takes. Goldie Dx 2/21/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mastescomy went well yesterday Goldie texas94

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 11:17AM Goldie wrote: Anne, Yes, I'm sorry, I did have the biopsy already and it was the pathology that told the dr. stage 1, grade 2, etc.   Pathololgy never said anything about nodes, I got that off the MRI when I was reading it over.  Thanks.
Posts.Title: Please help! Question on MRI report. Goldie Goldie

Posts.Content: Goldie wrote: I got a copy of my MRI report that dx'd me with bc of the left breast.  My docotr stated I appear Stage 1 with grade 2.  A large DCIS tumor and approx. 1 cm ITC.  He said he wouldn't know if any lymph nodes were affected until he performed my mastecomy. However, when I looked at the MRI report, it said, "Also present are left axillary enhancing node.  The internal mammary vessels are prominent." But it does not make any indication of suspicion of malignancy as it did with the tumors themsevles. Does this MRI report mean that my lymph nodes are in fact invovled and the doctor is just not telling me. I just had my bone scan and chest xray yesterday--don't know results and I'm just continuing to fear the worst. So when I read that in the MRI I'm panicking now. Anyone have any insight?????  Please. Goldie Dx 2/21/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Please help! Question on MRI report. Goldie Goldie

Posts.Content: Goldie wrote: Me again. I had my appt. at the University of Michigan yesterday after a day long series of tests and reviewing my pathology,they gave me several options for surgery.  the surgeon who did the biopsy said withoutknowing anyting more about nodes, it looked possibly like Stage i.  I have a 5 cm mass, 2 cm of that is idc and other 3 cm is DCIS.  They did an ultrasound on my armpit to look for any enlarged lymph nodes and found one. But both the technician and surgeon said it could be in response tot he large biopsy I had just had done last week. I pray that's all it is.  So next week I have to go in for a needle biopsy of that node to see if the cancer is in there and then a CT scan.  I told him I just want to have a double mastecomy.  I'm even thinking of having myovaries removed too.  He kept trying to tell me removing the healthy breast doesn't reduce my odds of recurrence that much or change my survival rates. Mammograms never caught my tumor it wasn't until my nipple was bleeding did someone order an MRI and ta, ta, cancer. I'm so terrifed it's in that node and has metastised through my body.   I did have a clear bone scan and chest xray. I can't stand the through of my three little girls watching me die from this. The doctor tells me I'm curable, but all I can keep thinking is that we don't know what got through the node or if I have mets. Can someone give me some hope please!  I feel so hopeless and I know I have to fight.  Love you guys. Goldie Dx 2/21/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I'm startng to feel so hopeless! Please help me out! Goldie dhettish

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 12:20PM Goldie wrote: Thanks for all the feedback.  But I've actually put a lot of thought into removing the healthy breast.  It would need to be reduced quite a bit anyway for balance.  In addition, my mother had bc at 50, my father had colon cancer, and I've already had thyroid cancer and now breast cancer and as far as early detection....four years of mammograms, sometimes two a year never showed the tumor in my left breast.  It wasn't until I had blood coming out of it did a doctor ask for a MRI for me that caught.  I also had pain associated in the nipple that no one could explain.  So my fear is that early detection did not work on the bad breast so I can't expect to catch it early in the other if it shows up there.  I have 3 little girls and have to do everything in my power to reduce the percentages of it coming back.
Posts.Title: I'm startng to feel so hopeless! Please help me out! Goldie dhettish

Posts.Content: Goldie wrote: Hi again.  I just had my left breast removed for bc, no nodes involved, even though surgeon had recommended a lumpetomy.  I've already let him know I would like to have the right breast removed when I go later for reconstruction, to try and increase my chances of eliminating a recurrance. I've read lots of articles that indicate preventative mastetomies can reduce your chances of getting bc by as much as 90 %.  I understand when he explained it's not 100% because some breast tissue remains, but he didn't seem as optimistic about removing the healthy breast at this time. I just feel I need to do everything I can. I'm 42 with 3 small girls.  Anyone have preventative mastetomy and anyone who has better information on how effective it truly is??? Thanks, Goldie Dx 2/21/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Preventative Mastectomies? Goldie BethNY

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 11:41AM Goldie wrote: I'm going tomoroww for my bone scan and chest exray and I'm just still sto terrrified of finding out it's somehwere else.  I won't even know about any nodes until my surgery.  Does anyone know with my pathology if it's common or not to have bone, lung and node involvement?  This waiting and fearing the worst is really getting to me. Thanks girls, Goldie
